GOD.content: secret letter becomes literature [Kafka] when it risks publicity, destinerrance, an archive to be inherited, when abandoned to its undecidability (is it the signature of father or son?)
GOD.linkedContent: secret letter becomes literature [Kafka] when it risks publicity, destinerrance, an archive to be inherited, when abandoned to its undecidability (is it the signature of father or son?)

GT.content: a gift is not signed, does not calculate w/ a time that would do it justice
GT.linkedContent: a gift is not signed, does not calculate w/ a time that would do it justice

AF.content: signature is btwn proper name & what it invented
AF.linkedContent: signature is btwn proper name & what it invented

AF.content: (what Yerushalmi wants from Freud, dying Freud [see POOF Aristotle’s dying sage says “friends, no friends”]) last word, last will, ultimate signature, uneffaceable countersignature
AF.linkedContent: (what Yerushalmi wants from Freud, dying Freud [see POOF Aristotle’s dying sage says “friends, no friends”]) last word, last will, ultimate signature, uneffaceable countersignature

FL.content: deconstruction is impossible possibility, [possible would make it calculable]; never applies itself to anything from the outside, auto-heterodeconstruction, open wound of such a signature
FL.linkedContent: deconstruction is impossible possibility, [possible would make it calculable]; never applies itself to anything from the outside, auto-heterodeconstruction, open wound of such a signature

FL.content: for Benjamin, text & signature are specters which exhibit & archive their implosion, in ruins, [Derrida now affirms this “stance”] such is status of deconstructive text: cannot escape law it enunciates, ruins & contaminates itself [at once founding/preserving], becomes specter of itself
FL.linkedContent: for Benjamin, text & signature are specters which exhibit & archive their implosion, in ruins, [Derrida now affirms this “stance”] such is status of deconstructive text: cannot escape law it enunciates, ruins & contaminates itself [at once founding/preserving], becomes specter of itself

FL.content: when we sign, we speak in non-constative, prescriptive, evaluative manner [re: end of Benjamin’s essay]
FL.linkedContent: when we sign, we speak in non-constative, prescriptive, evaluative manner [re: end of Benjamin’s essay]

BL.content: that which makes literature possible is outside literature
BL.linkedContent: that which makes literature possible is outside literature

BL.content: different periods of history of positive law give substance to literature, value of signatures [“authors”]
BL.linkedContent: different periods of history of positive law give substance to literature, value of signatures [“authors”]

LOBL.content: how can a translation be signed?

SPOM.content: stroke of genius, signature of the Thing “Shakespeare”: authorizes each translation, makes them possible without ever being reducible to them [Derrida is playing w/ the out-of-jointness of each translation of “time is out of joint”]
SPOM.linkedContent: stroke of genius, signature of the Thing “Shakespeare”: authorizes each translation, makes them possible without ever being reducible to them [Derrida is playing w/ the out-of-jointness of each translation of “time is out of joint”]

HERP.content: Heidegger’s 3 creative “Gewalten” of historial destiny: poet, thinker, statesman > their work as Schaffen carries seal or signature of originary polemos/Kampf
HERP.linkedContent: Heidegger’s 3 creative “Gewalten” of historial destiny: poet, thinker, statesman > their work as Schaffen carries seal or signature of originary polemos/Kampf

POOF.content: not to sign, not to assume an account
POOF.linkedContent: not to sign, not to assume an account

POOF.content: ridiculous fantasy/staging of death of friendship: friend signs your signature at your tomb > who never dreams such a scene?
POOF.linkedContent: ridiculous fantasy/staging of death of friendship: friend signs your signature at your tomb > who never dreams such a scene?

POOF.content: every instant begins at the end, address carries in its readability the signature of the addressee: it withdraws from space by penetrating it
POOF.linkedContent: every instant begins at the end, address carries in its readability the signature of the addressee: it withdraws from space by penetrating it

MPM.content: tropology of memory in autobiographical discourse > discourse as epitaph, signature of its own epitaph (prosopopoeia)
MPM.linkedContent: tropology of memory in autobiographical discourse > discourse as epitaph, signature of its own epitaph (prosopopoeia)

MPM.content: all relation to others carries signature of memoirs-from-beyond-the-grave
MPM.linkedContent: all relation to others carries signature of memoirs-from-beyond-the-grave

MPM.content: irony of using another signature to talk about yourself
MPM.linkedContent: irony of using another signature to talk about yourself

MPM.content: this allegorical story of signature includes theme of “Lazarus, arise!” a “ghost” story, resurrection
MPM.linkedContent: this allegorical story of signature includes theme of “Lazarus, arise!” a “ghost” story, resurrection

MPM.content: “must one at each instant reinvent filiation?” is this a signature of faithful memory or betrayal, figure of simulacrum?
MPM.linkedContent: “must one at each instant reinvent filiation?” is this a signature of faithful memory or betrayal, figure of simulacrum?

MPM.content: when de Man quotes Mallarmé’s “this shallow calumniated stream called death” from “Tomb of Verlaine” (signatory of epitaph always writes on his own tomb), Derrida tells us genealogy of genitives cannot be broken by cenotaph or cremation: the tomb of Verlaine of Mallarmé of Paul de Man
MPM.linkedContent: when de Man quotes Mallarmé’s “this shallow calumniated stream called death” from “Tomb of Verlaine” (signatory of epitaph always writes on his own tomb), Derrida tells us genealogy of genitives cannot be broken by cenotaph or cremation: the tomb of Verlaine of Mallarmé of Paul de Man

MPM.content: writing, as an event of signature, a signature which can only promise itself in the sense that its destination is barred, impasse of aporia
MPM.linkedContent: writing, as an event of signature, a signature which can only promise itself in the sense that its destination is barred, impasse of aporia

MPM.content: [re: de Man, word “deconstruction” inscribing itself instead of being erased] “always already” erases singularity of event, which is erased in its turn before signature of this word [“deconstruction”] > signature asserts itself as history insofar as origin of its “taking-place” is unlocatable
MPM.linkedContent: [re: de Man, word “deconstruction” inscribing itself instead of being erased] “always already” erases singularity of event, which is erased in its turn before signature of this word [“deconstruction”] > signature asserts itself as history insofar as origin of its “taking-place” is unlocatable

MPM.content: each deconstructive thinking constitutes a text which bears its rhetorical singularity (style of promise, figure of signature)
MPM.linkedContent: each deconstructive thinking constitutes a text which bears its rhetorical singularity (style of promise, figure of signature)

SEC.content: for Austin, signature is equal to verbal utterance coming from “I”, for signature to maintain itself: pure reproducibility of pure event
SEC.linkedContent: for Austin, signature is equal to verbal utterance coming from “I”, for signature to maintain itself: pure reproducibility of pure event

SEC.content: for Derrida, for a signature to function, to be legible, it must detach itself from present and singular intention of its production; its sameness alters its identity and singularity, divides the seal
SEC.linkedContent: for Derrida, for a signature to function, to be legible, it must detach itself from present and singular intention of its production; its sameness alters its identity and singularity, divides the seal

PAS.content: Derrida approaches Blanchot slowly, makes the go and come of Blanchot’s pas resonate, not dominate the text, approach event of his unheard of signature, plunge it back into son eau
PAS.linkedContent: Derrida approaches Blanchot slowly, makes the go and come of Blanchot’s pas resonate, not dominate the text, approach event of his unheard of signature, plunge it back into son eau

S.content: for Heidegger, signature of thought never individual, commits via community, people, in his or her own language; there are only some languages open to Being: German, Greek
S.linkedContent: for Heidegger, signature of thought never individual, commits via community, people, in his or her own language; there are only some languages open to Being: German, Greek

T.content: logic of event, structures of expropriation: timbre (tympanum), style and signature > same obliterating division of the proper, make every event possible, necessary, unfindable
T.linkedContent: logic of event, structures of expropriation: timbre (tympanum), style and signature > same obliterating division of the proper, make every event possible, necessary, unfindable

SH.content: poem is due its date, owes itself to its date as inmost concern, signature, owes itself to its secret, speaks of this date only insofar as it acquits itself > inscription breaks silence of pure singularity
SH.linkedContent: poem is due its date, owes itself to its date as inmost concern, signature, owes itself to its secret, speaks of this date only insofar as it acquits itself > inscription breaks silence of pure singularity

SH.content: dating amounts to signing; signature marks provenance of what is given (sent), destined (whether or not it arrives) > one signs a date from a given place
SH.linkedContent: dating amounts to signing; signature marks provenance of what is given (sent), destined (whether or not it arrives) > one signs a date from a given place

SH.content: date always bound up w/ a proper name > gives us to think an idiom, each time, barely translatable [Derrida is also referring to his French phrasing]
SH.linkedContent: date always bound up w/ a proper name > gives us to think an idiom, each time, barely translatable [Derrida is also referring to his French phrasing]

SH.content: signature not only recalls the vanished as vanished, the singular event, its ash > it gathers together a conjunction of singularities, a partaking in future of same date
SH.linkedContent: signature not only recalls the vanished as vanished, the singular event, its ash > it gathers together a conjunction of singularities, a partaking in future of same date

SH.content: pledge, complementary object divide in 2 to seal alliance > moment of engagement, signature, contract, ring
SH.linkedContent: pledge, complementary object divide in 2 to seal alliance > moment of engagement, signature, contract, ring

SH.content: wherever signature enters idiom, leaving trace of incision (unique & iterable, cryptic & readable), there’s a date
SH.linkedContent: wherever signature enters idiom, leaving trace of incision (unique & iterable, cryptic & readable), there’s a date

F.content: every “word” that says Thing in word-thing > several subjects, places, instances; Wolf Man inhabits forbidden desire to call himself by glorious word, can’t not break seal in signing
F.linkedContent: every “word” that says Thing in word-thing > several subjects, places, instances; Wolf Man inhabits forbidden desire to call himself by glorious word, can’t not break seal in signing

FWT.content: heir must respond to double injunction: reaffirm what comes “before us,” necessary (il faut) to appropriate a past fundamentally inappropriable, reaffirm, relaunch otherwise, keep alive
FWT.linkedContent: heir must respond to double injunction: reaffirm what comes “before us,” necessary (il faut) to appropriate a past fundamentally inappropriable, reaffirm, relaunch otherwise, keep alive

FWT.content: reaffirmation which continues & interrupts: one’s own decision as that of the other: signature against signature
FWT.linkedContent: reaffirmation which continues & interrupts: one’s own decision as that of the other: signature against signature

FWT.content: to invent one’s name, sign otherwise, in the name of the name passed down, if that’s possible
FWT.linkedContent: to invent one’s name, sign otherwise, in the name of the name passed down, if that’s possible

ROP.content: to say “we” when all alone, after the death of the other, is a common phenomena of destinerrance, of the letter’s never returning, une dérive interne, to which we have to return
ROP.linkedContent: to say “we” when all alone, after the death of the other, is a common phenomena of destinerrance, of the letter’s never returning, une dérive interne, to which we have to return

ROP.content: “we” modality of with, with the other, as guest, host, or parasite, we is always said by a single person, taking advantage, the one signs for the other (at the home of; apud, avuec, avoc, apud hoc)
ROP.linkedContent: “we” modality of with, with the other, as guest, host, or parasite, we is always said by a single person, taking advantage, the one signs for the other (at the home of; apud, avuec, avoc, apud hoc)

ROP.content: [Derrida excuses his gossiping on Lacan]he’s talking about tukhē, encounter, and what binds signature of event to theorem
ROP.linkedContent: [Derrida excuses his gossiping on Lacan]he’s talking about tukhē, encounter, and what binds signature of event to theorem

ROP.content: to say “we” when all alone, after the death of the other, is a common phenomena of destinerrance, of the letter’s never returning, une dérive interne, to which we have to return
ROP.linkedContent: to say “we” when all alone, after the death of the other, is a common phenomena of destinerrance, of the letter’s never returning, une dérive interne, to which we have to return

SP.content: déjà, nom de ce qui s’efface ou d’avance se soustrait, laissant néanmoins une marque, une signature soustraite dans cela même don il se retire [Derrida talking about “himself”]
SP.linkedContent: déjà, nom de ce qui s’efface ou d’avance se soustrait, laissant néanmoins une marque, une signature soustraite dans cela même don il se retire [Derrida talking about “himself”]

SP.content: does one assume one’s own signature? formulation of such question disqualified by structure of the signature: (la signature/tombe)
SP.linkedContent: does one assume one’s own signature? formulation of such question disqualified by structure of the signature: (la signature/tombe)

SP.content: la signature et le texte tombent l’un hors de l’autre, se sécrètent, se séparent, et s’excrètent, se forment de la coupure même qui les décapite, les échafaude en tronc sans tête, dès l’instant de leur itérabilité > expropriative commencement marks everything erected w/ structure of etron [fecal matter]
SP.linkedContent: la signature et le texte tombent l’un hors de l’autre, se sécrètent, se séparent, et s’excrètent, se forment de la coupure même qui les décapite, les échafaude en tronc sans tête, dès l’instant de leur itérabilité > expropriative commencement marks everything erected w/ structure of etron [fecal matter]

OTO.content: F.N. already a pseudonym, be immeasurably wary when we think we’re reading Nietzsche’s signature or “autograph”
OTO.linkedContent: F.N. already a pseudonym, be immeasurably wary when we think we’re reading Nietzsche’s signature or “autograph”

OTO.content: autobiographical récit, tells himself his life, affirms EROS, gratitude for gift (gift: establishment of my own credit w/ this name): EROS signs or seals > before such signature, my life may be mere prejudice
OTO.linkedContent: autobiographical récit, tells himself his life, affirms EROS, gratitude for gift (gift: establishment of my own credit w/ this name): EROS signs or seals > before such signature, my life may be mere prejudice

OTO.content: it is life, as the living feminine, that must return eternally, selectively > life allied to herself by nuptial annulus, wedding ring
OTO.linkedContent: it is life, as the living feminine, that must return eternally, selectively > life allied to herself by nuptial annulus, wedding ring

OTO.content: btwn title & book to come, exergue situates place from which life will be recited: yes, yes, amen, amen, I sign, I am in debt to “high noon” [instant of signature, no place]
OTO.linkedContent: btwn title & book to come, exergue situates place from which life will be recited: yes, yes, amen, amen, I sign, I am in debt to “high noon” [instant of signature, no place]

OTO.content: autobiography’s signature written in step not beyond, Nietzsche’s one foot beyond life: differance, allo-, thanatography of autobiography
OTO.linkedContent: autobiography’s signature written in step not beyond, Nietzsche’s one foot beyond life: differance, allo-, thanatography of autobiography

OTO.content: [re: signature w/out value, to which is juxtaposed untimely signature] Nietzsche: rights of genius have been democratized, everyone relieved of the labor to form oneself, of personal necessity of culture (Bildungsarbeit, Bildungsnot)
OTO.linkedContent: [re: signature w/out value, to which is juxtaposed untimely signature] Nietzsche: rights of genius have been democratized, everyone relieved of the labor to form oneself, of personal necessity of culture (Bildungsarbeit, Bildungsnot)

SW.content: bookmark the fringes, they served once to accomplish a commandment, may another be accomplished w/ them [Kitsour…] > that’s what I’m doing, à contretemps, et signe et livre et date
SW.linkedContent: bookmark the fringes, they served once to accomplish a commandment, may another be accomplished w/ them [Kitsour…] > that’s what I’m doing, à contretemps, et signe et livre et date

SW.content: this irreducible reality of an event (outside discourse but not text)—is so unlike you? > but, it’s the signature, a hem, on the edge, forever heterogenous, a tear, overlap, remaining caught in poetic stitches—thus the effects of anticipated iterability
SW.linkedContent: this irreducible reality of an event (outside discourse but not text)—is so unlike you? > but, it’s the signature, a hem, on the edge, forever heterogenous, a tear, overlap, remaining caught in poetic stitches—thus the effects of anticipated iterability

SW.content: signature (operation of poetic writing) must not be absolutely invulnerable: an “I” signs in the place of the wound (the other operates on us w/out knowing)—so virtual that it remains > bears bereaved memory of an unrefusable lesion > seems older than self: you may have forgotten it, but it carries on dictating all the blows of fate (as if we desired even the worst of them)
SW.linkedContent: signature (operation of poetic writing) must not be absolutely invulnerable: an “I” signs in the place of the wound (the other operates on us w/out knowing)—so virtual that it remains > bears bereaved memory of an unrefusable lesion > seems older than self: you may have forgotten it, but it carries on dictating all the blows of fate (as if we desired even the worst of them)

TB.content: untranslatability less to do w/ adequation than unique occurrence of a performative of force
TB.linkedContent: untranslatability less to do w/ adequation than unique occurrence of a performative of force

TB.content: translation: task of pure limit, an infinite labor to rejoin (doesn’t exclude gradations, virtuality, interval & in-btwn) > can one quote a signature?
TB.linkedContent: translation: task of pure limit, an infinite labor to rejoin (doesn’t exclude gradations, virtuality, interval & in-btwn) > can one quote a signature?

REST.content: Van Gogh left a trap, lacet (snare) [at bottom right corner of picture, cf. p. 258] > cette boucle étrange, une sorte de noeud esquissé, untied shoes, forms an open circle, pincers or key ring, a leash (laisse), as though taking the place of his signature
REST.linkedContent: Van Gogh left a trap, lacet (snare) [at bottom right corner of picture, cf. p. 258] > cette boucle étrange, une sorte de noeud esquissé, untied shoes, forms an open circle, pincers or key ring, a leash (laisse), as though taking the place of his signature

DST.content: imprint and caesura, sharp-edged signature (empreinte et césure, la signature aiguë), interrupts most powerful filiations > ineluctably: when tradition can’t secure what it repeats as its own traditionality (exemplarity, repetition, identification, imitation)
DST.linkedContent: imprint and caesura, sharp-edged signature (empreinte et césure, la signature aiguë), interrupts most powerful filiations > ineluctably: when tradition can’t secure what it repeats as its own traditionality (exemplarity, repetition, identification, imitation)

DST.content: signature interrupts, or rather marks w/ incision, the fold along which metaphysical ontomimetology is destined to divide, desist [ontomimetology in Plato, Aristotle, Hegel, Heidegger, and more surreptitiously in Nietzsche, Freud, Lacan]
DST.linkedContent: signature interrupts, or rather marks w/ incision, the fold along which metaphysical ontomimetology is destined to divide, desist [ontomimetology in Plato, Aristotle, Hegel, Heidegger, and more surreptitiously in Nietzsche, Freud, Lacan]

DST.content: we are constituted by this rhythm, (de-)constituted by marks of this “caesuraed” stamp, rhythmotypy as divided idiom in us of désistance > no subject w/out signature of this rhythm
DST.linkedContent: we are constituted by this rhythm, (de-)constituted by marks of this “caesuraed” stamp, rhythmotypy as divided idiom in us of désistance > no subject w/out signature of this rhythm

PIO.content: Derrida’s discourse on invention, not inventive through & through: must sign exploiting rule-governed resources > all comes down to that signed innovation
PIO.linkedContent: Derrida’s discourse on invention, not inventive through & through: must sign exploiting rule-governed resources > all comes down to that signed innovation

PIO.content: invention is not natural, though often related to origin, genius, generation > thus question of son, signature & name
PIO.linkedContent: invention is not natural, though often related to origin, genius, generation > thus question of son, signature & name

PIO.content: universality (ideal objectivity, unlimited recurrence) in invention blurs signature of invention: name of individual (singular empirical entity) is associated w/ invention in inessential, extrinsic, accidental, aleatory way > this gives rise to enormous problem of property rights
PIO.linkedContent: universality (ideal objectivity, unlimited recurrence) in invention blurs signature of invention: name of individual (singular empirical entity) is associated w/ invention in inessential, extrinsic, accidental, aleatory way > this gives rise to enormous problem of property rights

RM.content: for Heidegger, most grave and engraving signature of decision engages/allies 2 families in German language: 1. Ziehen (Zug, Bezug, Gezüge, durchziehen, entziehen) 2. Reissen (Riss, Aufriss, Umriss, Grundriss, etc.)
RM.linkedContent: for Heidegger, most grave and engraving signature of decision engages/allies 2 families in German language: 1. Ziehen (Zug, Bezug, Gezüge, durchziehen, entziehen) 2. Reissen (Riss, Aufriss, Umriss, Grundriss, etc.)

RM.content: trait (that plural word): possibility of language, logos, lexis, inscription
RM.linkedContent: trait (that plural word): possibility of language, logos, lexis, inscription

RM.content: Heidegger’s nontautological fashion (like Sprache, Ereignis): trait treats or treats itself, traces the trait, retraces or re-treats the withdrawal > a strange contract that doesn’t precede, for once, its own signature (sa propre signature), and therefore carries it off (et donc l’emporte)
RM.linkedContent: Heidegger’s nontautological fashion (like Sprache, Ereignis): trait treats or treats itself, traces the trait, retraces or re-treats the withdrawal > a strange contract that doesn’t precede, for once, its own signature (sa propre signature), and therefore carries it off (et donc l’emporte)

PF.content: [re: Peggy Kamuf’s collection] invention: 1) discovery of what appeared already to be found there 2) making exist what’s not yet there: becomes public/readable at instant of irreplaceable signature that interrupts/displaces continuity of unveiling discovery
PF.linkedContent: [re: Peggy Kamuf’s collection] invention: 1) discovery of what appeared already to be found there 2) making exist what’s not yet there: becomes public/readable at instant of irreplaceable signature that interrupts/displaces continuity of unveiling discovery

TR.content: “l’oeuvre has a virtual future only by surviving or cutting itself off from its presumed responsible signatory” [logic of machine in l’oeuvre]
TR.linkedContent: “l’oeuvre has a virtual future only by surviving or cutting itself off from its presumed responsible signatory” [logic of machine in l’oeuvre]

IW.content: Fichte’s great “discovery”: ego cogito is national, Self is social, in essence a national Self, cogito not formal [Kant] but in relation to other, a history, a language, substantially national
IW.linkedContent: Fichte’s great “discovery”: ego cogito is national, Self is social, in essence a national Self, cogito not formal [Kant] but in relation to other, a history, a language, substantially national

IW.content: “I” signs first in its spiritual language

PJP.content: narrative of a disappearance: signature gets erased moment it enters literature [like question in EJQB]
PJP.linkedContent: narrative of a disappearance: signature gets erased moment it enters literature [like question in EJQB]

PJP.content: ultimate signature (last pages of book) says something of debt that remains unpaid > no scene of perjury w/out forgiveness
PJP.linkedContent: ultimate signature (last pages of book) says something of debt that remains unpaid > no scene of perjury w/out forgiveness

PJP.content: forgive me, we say to us
PJP.linkedContent: forgive me, we say to us

EL.content: the vengeance of language (language as name of God) > a debt that leaves its signature in the language will be incurred by innocents, archiguilty, generations to come
EL.linkedContent: the vengeance of language (language as name of God) > a debt that leaves its signature in the language will be incurred by innocents, archiguilty, generations to come

EL.content: this is a logic that the cogito, practico-transcendental egology, cannot comprehend [i.e. cogito can’t comprehend language?]
EL.linkedContent: this is a logic that the cogito, practico-transcendental egology, cannot comprehend [i.e. cogito can’t comprehend language?]

EL.content: God’s voice sealed, on reserve in sacred language, like a signature, the oath of the covenant or faith tying us to God: content of this hidden speech will take form again, meaning will take on form in manifestation, to hear & to say will renew the covenant
EL.linkedContent: God’s voice sealed, on reserve in sacred language, like a signature, the oath of the covenant or faith tying us to God: content of this hidden speech will take form again, meaning will take on form in manifestation, to hear & to say will renew the covenant

EL.content: sacred language: “con-juration" itself (conjuration btwn God & us)

+R.content: Derrida yielded to Adami (hooked like a fish [hostage]), as if his angular signature was waiting for me [Derrida], a stupefying advance > it became Derrida's business, made him speak
+R.linkedContent: Derrida yielded to Adami (hooked like a fish [hostage]), as if his angular signature was waiting for me [Derrida], a stupefying advance > it became Derrida's business, made him speak

+R.content: what is detached from my signature, da, a piece (morceau) of the other’s name, one of the most obsessive motifs in Glas
+R.linkedContent: what is detached from my signature, da, a piece (morceau) of the other’s name, one of the most obsessive motifs in Glas

+R.content: [re: Adami] detailing of extracts, fragments detachable as signatures (typewriter, pen case, umbrella, spectacles, etc.) > why de-tail [dé-tailler: cut out]?
+R.linkedContent: [re: Adami] detailing of extracts, fragments detachable as signatures (typewriter, pen case, umbrella, spectacles, etc.) > why de-tail [dé-tailler: cut out]?

C.content: bananas [re: Titus-Carmel’s The Great Cultu…] would be copies of copies w/out example, phantasmata, if force of ductus did not carry the remainder beyond any phantasy, beyond the signature, proper name, nameable [cf. pp. 220-21 also beyond hierarchy]
C.linkedContent: bananas [re: Titus-Carmel’s The Great Cultu…] would be copies of copies w/out example, phantasmata, if force of ductus did not carry the remainder beyond any phantasy, beyond the signature, proper name, nameable [cf. pp. 220-21 also beyond hierarchy]

C.content: cartouche: puts itself to work, forms part of the work by inscribing (itself) (as) the title, signature, autobiographical performative of the signatory
C.linkedContent: cartouche: puts itself to work, forms part of the work by inscribing (itself) (as) the title, signature, autobiographical performative of the signatory

C.content: I am myself cartouche and cartouches(s) in the plural: “I” sign myself to death as soon as there’s the title, reduce myself to first heading, capital, shrunken head
C.linkedContent: I am myself cartouche and cartouches(s) in the plural: “I” sign myself to death as soon as there’s the title, reduce myself to first heading, capital, shrunken head

C.content: Cartouches, its singular performance (hapax, only once) simultaneously entitles & signs: I sign, therefore we sign cartouche(s) [m/f]
C.linkedContent: Cartouches, its singular performance (hapax, only once) simultaneously entitles & signs: I sign, therefore we sign cartouche(s) [m/f]

LI.content: [re: neologism texter] signature, événement qu’on texte: process of iteration, like surnombre [of Dissemination], marks pluralization that fractures the event, the unique, while causing it to occur (arriver)
LI.linkedContent: [re: neologism texter] signature, événement qu’on texte: process of iteration, like surnombre [of Dissemination], marks pluralization that fractures the event, the unique, while causing it to occur (arriver)

LI.content: dispatch should have been signed, which I do, and counterfeit, here, where? [Remark at end of SEC, also see GT]
LI.linkedContent: dispatch should have been signed, which I do, and counterfeit, here, where? [Remark at end of SEC, also see GT]

LI.content: can a signature be cited? what are the consequences?
LI.linkedContent: can a signature be cited? what are the consequences?

LI.content: signature is on the edge of the text (neither inside nor outside)
LI.linkedContent: signature is on the edge of the text (neither inside nor outside)

LI.content: can a proper name or a signature be translated?
LI.linkedContent: can a proper name or a signature be translated?

LI.content: consequences of fact that signature is imitable, that I imitate it, are unlimited, unlimitable
LI.linkedContent: consequences of fact that signature is imitable, that I imitate it, are unlimited, unlimitable

LI.content: Derrida introduces Sarl (société à responsabilité limitée), wrong to find his discourse polemical > desires & phantasms at stake in proper name, signature, copyright
LI.linkedContent: Derrida introduces Sarl (société à responsabilité limitée), wrong to find his discourse polemical > desires & phantasms at stake in proper name, signature, copyright

NOY.content: the “second” yes, doit arriver comme un renouvellement absolu, the structural “forgetting” of fidelity
NOY.linkedContent: the “second” yes, doit arriver comme un renouvellement absolu, the structural “forgetting” of fidelity

NOY.content: “grâce… à la menace de cet oubli [the cutting off, the becoming unique, the divisibility contre laquelle une signature se tend] la mémoire de la promesse, la promesse même peut franchir son premier pas, à savoir le second” ——yes, (already but always) faithful countersignature, can’t be counted: it always sends itself off in number (il s’envoie toujours en nombre)
NOY.linkedContent: “grâce… à la menace de cet oubli [the cutting off, the becoming unique, the divisibility contre laquelle une signature se tend] la mémoire de la promesse, la promesse même peut franchir son premier pas, à savoir le second” ——yes, (already but always) faithful countersignature, can’t be counted: it always sends itself off in number (il s’envoie toujours en nombre)

ATM.content: what to make of a signature [Levinas’] when “il aura obligé,” when Il signs in his place?
ATM.linkedContent: what to make of a signature [Levinas’] when “il aura obligé,” when Il signs in his place?

ATM.content: how does one hear “one must” in Derrida’s polysemic “l’oeuvre d’E.L. aura obligé”
ATM.linkedContent: how does one hear “one must” in Derrida’s polysemic “l’oeuvre d’E.L. aura obligé”

ATM.content: how to cite when Levinas places the whole language (French & Western) btwn quotation marks? at same time “he” is in quotation marks: the nameless signatory w/out authorial signature, “he” who undersigns every work, met en oeuvre tout ouvrage
ATM.linkedContent: how to cite when Levinas places the whole language (French & Western) btwn quotation marks? at same time “he” is in quotation marks: the nameless signatory w/out authorial signature, “he” who undersigns every work, met en oeuvre tout ouvrage

ATM.content: infinite law of quotation marks suspends all reference, work enclosed in a borderless context it gives to itself (se donne à elle-même), while making absolute reference to command of tout autre
ATM.linkedContent: infinite law of quotation marks suspends all reference, work enclosed in a borderless context it gives to itself (se donne à elle-même), while making absolute reference to command of tout autre

E.content: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature
E.linkedContent: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature

E.content: [re: disinterested pleasure] a moral revenue drawn from a natural production w/out interest to us; one takes wealth w/out interest, the singular moral surplus value of sans—still, the trace (Spur) of a purpose in nature is what makes our stock in moral value rise
E.linkedContent: [re: disinterested pleasure] a moral revenue drawn from a natural production w/out interest to us; one takes wealth w/out interest, the singular moral surplus value of sans—still, the trace (Spur) of a purpose in nature is what makes our stock in moral value rise

E.content: the without of pure detachment is a language nature speaks to us, “she who loves to encrypt herself and record her signature on things”
E.linkedContent: the without of pure detachment is a language nature speaks to us, “she who loves to encrypt herself and record her signature on things”

CIN.content: [re: taped readings of CIN] two voices yield to “another voice,” voice of signatory of text is figure of only one among others, not clear if this figure is masculine or woman
CIN.linkedContent: [re: taped readings of CIN] two voices yield to “another voice,” voice of signatory of text is figure of only one among others, not clear if this figure is masculine or woman

CIN.content: Derrida gives Cinder a proper name, is she the signatory of this text?
CIN.linkedContent: Derrida gives Cinder a proper name, is she the signatory of this text?

CIN.content: why the phrase “il y a là cendre” doesn’t belong to him [Derrida] > cinder lent, given, to so many others, cinder remains virginal (the only thing he loves), in tact (intacte), the sentence doesn’t even say the cinder
CIN.linkedContent: why the phrase “il y a là cendre” doesn’t belong to him [Derrida] > cinder lent, given, to so many others, cinder remains virginal (the only thing he loves), in tact (intacte), the sentence doesn’t even say the cinder

BSi.content: poetic signature: not essence but where poem is coming/going: frees itself, by art, from art
BSi.linkedContent: poetic signature: not essence but where poem is coming/going: frees itself, by art, from art

OG.content: writing: absence of signatory/referent, a “fixité” different from speech’s, a monstrosity, écart naturel dans la nature > must contain it like a leper
OG.linkedContent: writing: absence of signatory/referent, a “fixité” different from speech’s, a monstrosity, écart naturel dans la nature > must contain it like a leper

ATAP.content: general narrator at moment of signature calls itself the witness (martyrōn, testimonium)
ATAP.linkedContent: general narrator at moment of signature calls itself the witness (martyrōn, testimonium)

UWC.content: [the event, the unconditional] matter of the sense of sense [meaning of meaning?] > up to you now, up to others—signatories are also addressees
UWC.linkedContent: [the event, the unconditional] matter of the sense of sense [meaning of meaning?] > up to you now, up to others—signatories are also addressees

EU.content: [re: Kant’s University] monogram, un germe (Keim), an elliptic, enveloped signature—completes itself, pre-destined form
EU.linkedContent: [re: Kant’s University] monogram, un germe (Keim), an elliptic, enveloped signature—completes itself, pre-destined form

SPEC.content: Indra–Varuna (Abraham–Isaac-like) interlace their names w/out revenir sur eux-mêmes (not a ring) > cannot close, so enclose each other > always a [double signature]
SPEC.linkedContent: Indra–Varuna (Abraham–Isaac-like) interlace their names w/out revenir sur eux-mêmes (not a ring) > cannot close, so enclose each other > always a [double signature]

SPEC.content: the contractual institution that permits one to say “je-nous” > Freud’s signature engageant et représentant tous les tenants de la théorie: ça marche et fait marcher comme ça [is Derrida speaking about himself too?]
SPEC.linkedContent: the contractual institution that permits one to say “je-nous” > Freud’s signature engageant et représentant tous les tenants de la théorie: ça marche et fait marcher comme ça [is Derrida speaking about himself too?]

SPEC.content: one gives oneself one’s own movement, one inherits from oneself all the time
SPEC.linkedContent: one gives oneself one’s own movement, one inherits from oneself all the time

SPEC.content: sufficient provisions so ghost can always step up to the cashier (passer à la caisse); all that’s necessary is to pronounce a name guaranteeing a signature, one thinks
SPEC.linkedContent: sufficient provisions so ghost can always step up to the cashier (passer à la caisse); all that’s necessary is to pronounce a name guaranteeing a signature, one thinks

SPEC.content: greatest pleasure, play w/ the dummy (le mort), [Ernst, Freud] speaks to himself telephonically, make himself re-, acc. law of PP: signing, contracting w/ himself
SPEC.linkedContent: greatest pleasure, play w/ the dummy (le mort), [Ernst, Freud] speaks to himself telephonically, make himself re-, acc. law of PP: signing, contracting w/ himself

SPEC.content: complex scene of signature in which inscription arrives only to erase itself
SPEC.linkedContent: complex scene of signature in which inscription arrives only to erase itself

SPEC.content: Freud’s signature in form of “if I wish to,” a seal, “auto-critique” w/out pity > what more to say after that? [cf. SW after Derrida, nobody can discover something behind veil]
SPEC.linkedContent: Freud’s signature in form of “if I wish to,” a seal, “auto-critique” w/out pity > what more to say after that? [cf. SW after Derrida, nobody can discover something behind veil]

FV.content: Lacan translates Wiederholungszwang as “repetition automatism,” the pre-eminence of signifier over signified > consequence: “literary” text does w/out reference to author [Derrida implies that Lacan takes, at times, his distrust of psychobiography too far in other direction: formalist neutralization of effects of signature]
FV.linkedContent: Lacan translates Wiederholungszwang as “repetition automatism,” the pre-eminence of signifier over signified > consequence: “literary” text does w/out reference to author [Derrida implies that Lacan takes, at times, his distrust of psychobiography too far in other direction: formalist neutralization of effects of signature]

FV.content: Lacan is missing an elaboration of frame, signature, parergon > this lack permits scene of signifier to be reconstructed into a signified (inevitable process in logic of sign)
FV.linkedContent: Lacan is missing an elaboration of frame, signature, parergon > this lack permits scene of signifier to be reconstructed into a signified (inevitable process in logic of sign)

FV.content: signer dispossessed [re: The Purloined…], signature in quotations: ce reste est encore de la littérature
FV.linkedContent: signer dispossessed [re: The Purloined…], signature in quotations: ce reste est encore de la littérature

WBH.content: women’s studies has uplifted from repression all sorts of forbidden feminine signatures
WBH.linkedContent: women’s studies has uplifted from repression all sorts of forbidden feminine signatures

WBH.content: Kafka’s “Before the Law” is the Law, his signature, or signature of the text, makes the law
WBH.linkedContent: Kafka’s “Before the Law” is the Law, his signature, or signature of the text, makes the law

WBH.content: receiver as determining factor of gift, one who responds, performativity of text produces receiver w/out pre-existing [him/her/it]
WBH.linkedContent: receiver as determining factor of gift, one who responds, performativity of text produces receiver w/out pre-existing [him/her/it]

WBH.content: Declaration of Independence signed by God, signs American people into existence, they didn’t exist before it
WBH.linkedContent: Declaration of Independence signed by God, signs American people into existence, they didn’t exist before it

WBH.content: it is by the gift that Law is produced, the signature engenders sender, receiver, signer
WBH.linkedContent: it is by the gift that Law is produced, the signature engenders sender, receiver, signer

WBH.content: promise in every speech act, promise not simply performative
WBH.linkedContent: promise in every speech act, promise not simply performative

WBH.content: if signature, or all that amounts to it, can’t rely on ready determination (is performative), then you can’t rely on sexual opposition n
WBH.linkedContent: if signature, or all that amounts to it, can’t rely on ready determination (is performative), then you can’t rely on sexual opposition n

CHOR.content: no monological discourse, no mono-sexual discourse, necessity for a chorus, a choreographic text w/ polysexual signatures
CHOR.linkedContent: no monological discourse, no mono-sexual discourse, necessity for a chorus, a choreographic text w/ polysexual signatures
